post.body:
IT'S A BIG SYSTEM - AND IT'S MOVING!!

Migrating GabNewsToday.com to GabNews.com today! Gab.com has graciously acquired the GabNews.com domain and has handed over control for management by me.

My goal is to be and provide the official news nerve center for Gab.com driven by members in the direction they want. All of this is happening to make keeping up with news, podcasts, and other online content as easy and fun as possible.

Gab News is a complex system and is made of a load balancer, two front-end application servers, Redis and MongoDB database servers, and the Gab News Worker (GNW). Each of these components communicates with the others in various ways, and they all have to be wired up together to work in concert to deliver what you will soon know as GabNews.com.

I'd like to tell you a little bit about each component, what it does, why it's there, and help you understand a little bit about what actually goes into a system like this.

Load Balancer
The load balancer is the component that actually accepts in your incoming request for news, chooses a front-end application server, and forwards your request to it for service. The load balancer monitors each of the front-end application servers and ensures that each request is receiving the best available service.

Application Server
The application server(s) actually implement Gab News. They are the "web servers" that process incoming requests for information, resolve those requests against the databases (plural), and format the data as HTML for consumption by your phone, tablet, or computer.

Gab News Worker
The Gab News Worker is a specialized process that monitors the system's RSS feeds for new articles, ingests the articles, indexes them for search, runs the Agents, and (soon) sends notifications about new stories/episodes for every user on the system. The workers are deployed in hives and collaborate to distribute the load of ingesting news, generating notifications, etc.

Redis Database
Redis, an in-memory fancy key/value store, is responsible for the "fast path" data flows within the system. Things that can be cached, like the first page of articles per feed, are stored in Redis for fast retrieval without sorts and application logic. User session records are also stored in Redis along with some global statistics and analysis data.

MongoDB Database
MongoDB is being used as the primary content store. All news articles are stored in MongoDB along with user account, newsfeed subscriptions, per-user Agent configurations, and more. Mongo has been deployed in a high-availability cluster with sharding, which basically just means: BRING THE NEWS!

Additional Components
Gab News also includes the admin server, system monitor, and the git repository server.

The admin server is what allows me to administer the system, review feed suggestions, add new feeds, manage existing content and adjust system settings.

The system monitor monitors all configured components to make sure they are healthy. It sends requests that generate deterministic responses and has the ability to dig into the databases and ensure responses from the front-end are correct. If anything screws up, I know within seconds. It's why you don't see errors at the site.

Finally, there is the git repository server. I am not using github. All source code for all components is stored in this repository along with all history of every change made filed in branches and tagged releases. I push many changes per day...all day...and my git server is what makes sure those changes happen exactly as planned.

post.body:
I'm very late to the part but the fight was amazing. Khabib bounced McGregor's head off the canvas. 

What happened after the fight? Pure disappointment. How the fuck will they renew their visas?

Thanks for the understanding.

post.body: Hey everyone! Since we updated GabTV recently, you guys have been uploading A LOT more videos than before. We're upgrading our encoding mechanism now to process videos so much faster. Thanks for your patience, we're about to ship the update.

post.body:
Here is the reality. One of @Patrick_little‚Äôs posts unquestionably breaks our user guidelines‚Äîand probably US law. The other is offensive and edgy and something we obviously don‚Äôt agree with, but there is much worse on Twitter/Facebook/Reddit about white people that is allowed to stay. 

This is a very serious situation. We need to make real decisions that impact the hundreds of thousands of users on this site and our shareholders, customers, etc. It‚Äôs not a game.

Patrick stated multiple times today that he was going to delete the posts himself. 

Now he is playing games. He is not a man of his word, so we took action and removed both posts. We had no choice. 

We are actively looking into other hosting providers and our longterm goal is building our own infrastructure. Both of these will take time. Time we do not have under Microsoft‚Äôs 48 hour game. 

We believe this was the best decision for the longevity of the platform and the war against Silicon Valley.
